text: police cars have been set on fire and
shops have been looted in a sixth night
of unrest across the United States
curfews are in force in nearly 40 cities
including the capital Washington DC as
protests continue over the death of a
black man in police custody
a North America correspondent David
Willis has this report
[Music]
this country is walking a fine and
dangerous line
[Applause]
as a large and angry crowd gathered
outside the White House it emerged that
at one point at the height of the
protests here on Friday President Trump
was ushered into an underground bunker
by members of The Secret Service in the
interests of his own safety on several
occasions in the last few days
demonstrators here have attempted to
scale the walls and many were reluctant
to conform with a newly imposed
overnight curfew as the president
hunkered down his presumptive Democratic
presidential opponent tweeted a picture
of himself at the scene of one of last
night's protests Joe Biden promised to
listen to the demonstrators and help
shape the movement for reform many
protests have been peaceful and in
Minneapolis where all this began a week
ago there was a moment when protesters
and a National Guard officer came
together
[Music]
you become nonetheless George Floyd's
arrest on a Minneapolis street corner
and his frantic pleas for help have
given rise to one of the most turbulent
periods in recent American history the
white police officer pictured holding
his knee - mr. Floyd's neck is due to
appear in court later today
Derrick Shaw VIN is facing charges of
murder and manslaughter but three other
officers involved in mr. Floyd's arrest
us still at large and there are growing
calls for them to be brought to justice
as well Donald Trump has described these
riots as domestic terrorism and blamed
them on far left anarchist groups but
there are those who believe at a
potential in pivotal moment in the
struggle for racial justice here that
without violence their voices will not
be heard the president has called on
state officials to deploy the National
Guard in cities where the violence has
grown increasingly out of hand but such
is the extent of the crisis that he's
facing growing calls to address the
nation from The Oval Office David Willis
BBC News Los Angeles
I'm joined now by hen Wilcox who's a
farmer and an event organizer who's been
at the protest in Olympia in Washington
State thank you very much for joining us
what was the protest like where you are
well yeah it was in downtown Olympia and
when I when I arrived there the police
were extremely aggressive within a
couple minutes of me being there there
was pepper balls and flash bangs and
rubber bullets that were being hit at
the protesters and and I mean like
protester isn't even quite like the
great way to like encapsulate like what
how people are showing up right now I
think that rebels and rebellion I think
are much more accurate terms to describe
the the mood and actions that people are
taking we're seeing some footage
actually that you shot yourself while
out on the streets joining those
protests
what was it that made you decide to join
this protest well um you know I mean I
growing up in the United States
you you start to get really you see the
pattern that policing happens in this
United States and and obviously I mean
I'm white and so a lot of that hasn't
come down on me personally but but
eventually but I've had enough
interactions with the police like doing
political engagements in the past that I
really kind of see the ways and modes in
which they operate and that and that
submission and violence's are the only
like languages that they speak and those
are the only things that they that they
know how to do and and you know at the
end of the day I just like refuse and
rebel against like this type of system
where apparently black you know
murdering black people is necessary to
the functioning of the system I mean
that's like if if we haven't learned
that lesson after the whole history of
the United States then I don't know how
many more times we need to learn it I
mean the United States police force was
organized and formalized around catching
slaves and so there's you know not a lot
has changed Donald Trump has described
the riots as domestic terrorism what's
your response to the way he's been
handling this well
you know first of all I think it was
just like a day or two ago was the
anniversary of Donald Trump's father
being arrested at a Ku Klux Klan rally
you know so it's like Apple hasn't
fallen very far from the tree you know I
think that I think Donald Trump is
irrelevant right now I think that the
really interesting thing that that I've
noticed about this political moment is
that people don't care what the
politicians have to say people don't
care what the mayor's have to say people
don't care they are not waiting any
longer for things to change you know
they're making it happen right
and I think that like when like the
thing that a lot of people have been
starting to focus on is like oh the good
protestor the bad protestor the
instigator polluting the violence but
like the thing that people first of all
my response to that is that the outside
agitator again this type of rhetoric
goes all the way back to when slavery
was more prevalent in the u.s. when
slave revolt to happen they would say
that it was northern agitators who came
to the south and agitated the slaves to
rise up because they just couldn't
believe that black folks would revolt on
their own will and so it's just
continuing this hundreds of years old
rhetoric that's extremely racist and so
you know people people don't care
anymore
and they're they're gonna make it happen
and also talking about Minneapolis like
the the violence and the looting and the
destruction that happened it's not just
random the target that was looted was
was when that was built people were very
already frustrated and angry about that
and the condos that were built the to
rent those it's two thousand five
hundred American dollars a month to be
able to live in those and so it's like
the world around us and like and black
folks especially like it's just like not
being built for people and so sorry to
interrupt but obviously what you're
describing there is you see this as a
lot of history that is bubbling up and
has now come to this point do you

everybody thought that oh the political

that it's possibly a pitiful moment and
it depends on on what we do and if we

will you you continue to protest and

mean I think that like I think that we
are gonna keep on pushing you know I
think and again it's like how many how

over and over and over and I mean and
that's the thing that we need to realize

is what's happening and it's like were
